Consensus ALADIN: A Framework for Distributed Optimization and Its Application in Federated Learning

Xu Du,¬† Jingzhe Wang X.Du is with the Institute of Mathematics HNAS, Henan Academy of Science, Zhengzhou, China. E-mail: duxu@shanghaitech.edu.cn Jingzhe Wang is with the Department of Informatics & Networked Systems, School of Computing and Information, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA, USA. E-mail: jiw148@pitt.edu
Abstract

This paper investigates algorithms for solving distributed consensus optimization problems that are non-convex. Since Typical ALADIN (Typical Augmented Lagrangian based Alternating Direction Inexact Newton Method, T-ALADIN for short)[1] is a well-performed algorithm treating distributed optimization problems that are non-convex, directly adopting T-ALADIN to those of consensus is a natural approach. However, T-ALADIN typically results in high communication and computation overhead, which makes such an approach far from efficient. In this paper, we propose a new variant of the ALADIN family, coined consensus ALADIN (C-ALADIN for short). C-ALADIN inherits all the good properties of T-ALADIN, such as the local linear or super-linear convergence rate and the local convergence guarantees for non-convex optimization problems; besides, C-ALADIN offers unique improvements in terms of communication efficiency and computational efficiency. Moreover, C-ALADIN involves a reduced version, in comparison with Consensus ADMM (Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers) [3], showing significant convergence performance, even without the help of second-order information. We also propose a practical version of C-ALADIN, named FedALADIN, that seamlessly serves the emerging federated learning applications, which expands the reach of our proposed C-ALADIN. We provide numerical experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of C-ALADIN. The results show that C-ALADIN has significant improvements in convergence performance.

Index Terms:
Distributed Consensus Optimization, Algorithm Efficiency, Convergence Analysis, Federated Learning

1 Introduction

In recent years, distributed optimization algorithms have received a lot of attention due to developments in numerical optimal control [4], smart grid [5], wireless communication[6], game theory[7], and machine learning[8]. In the field of distributed optimization algorithm design, solving distributed non-convex problems efficiently has always been the direction of people‚Äôs efforts. To deal with non-convexity, in this paper, we follow this direction and propose a novel algorithmic framework for distributed non-convex consensus optimization.

1.1 The Road to Consensus ALADIN

We start with introducing distributed optimization¬†(DO for short) problems. DO problems are generally formulated in the fashion of mathematical programming, where separable objectives are linearly coupled by mùëöm equality constraints. Formally, it can be described as follows:

minŒæi‚àà‚Ñùni‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(Œæi)s.t.‚àëi=1NAi‚ÄãŒæi=b|Œº.formulae-sequencesubscriptsubscriptùúâùëñsuperscript‚Ñùsubscriptùëõùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùúâùëñstsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùê¥ùëñsubscriptùúâùëñconditionalùëèùúá\begin{split}\min_{\xi_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}}}\;\;&\mathop{\sum}_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\xi_{i})\\ \mathrm{s.t.}\;\;&\mathop{\sum}_{i=1}^{N}A_{i}\xi_{i}=b\;|\mu.\end{split} (1)

Here, the coupling matrices Ai‚àà‚Ñùni√ómsubscriptùê¥ùëñsuperscript‚ÑùsubscriptùëõùëñùëöA_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n_{i}\times m} and the coupling parameter b‚àà‚Ñùmùëèsuperscript‚Ñùùëöb\in\mathbb{R}^{m} are given. The dimension nisubscriptùëõùëñn_{i} of private variables Œæisubscriptùúâùëñ\xi_{i}s are potentially different. Œº‚àà‚Ñùmùúásuperscript‚Ñùùëö\mu\in\mathbb{R}^{m} indicates the corresponding dual variable of the coupling constraints. When the objective fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}s are convex, there are some classical algorithms that can be used to solve it, such as dual decomposition (DD) [9, 10], and ADMM [3]. As a special case of DO, distributed consensus (DC) optimization problems meet all the challenges such as convergence theory for non-convex cases. The main difference of DO and DC is that DC has a global variable to which all the private variables will converge (detailed descriptions will be shown in Section 2.1).

As milestone research of DC, [11] shows that Consensus ADMM [3], under some assumptions, has a linear convergence rate for DC problems that are strongly convex. We refer [12] as a survey paper for more details. Notice that, similar to Consensus ADMM, current algorithms such as DGD [13], EXTRA [14] only have convergence guarantees for convex problems in the area of DC. However, many practical problems [4], especially those met in federated learning¬†(FL)[15], are non-convex. When meeting such problems, the above algorithms cannot provide satisfactory solutions in general.

To solve such non-convex problems, in literature, T-ALADIN is a state-of-the-art algorithm that can provide theoretical local convergence guarantee. Technically, T-ALADIN can be regarded as a successful combination of ADMM and sequential quadratic programming (SQP). Details can be found in Subsection 2.2. To date, T-ALADIN has several elegant successors [16, 17, 18, 19] and already shown effectiveness in many applications [20, 16, 17, 21]. From the above facts, to solve distributed consensus problems that are non-convex, directly adopting T-ALADIN seems very natural. However, such a trivial approach meets the following challenges: first, T-ALADIN will bring a large number of constraints in the coupled QP step (details can be found in (8)), and the dimension of the corresponding dual variable Œºùúá\mu will be extremely large; second, the T-ALADIN structure inevitably depends on the uploading of the first and second order information (details can be found in(7)) from the agents and downloading of the updated primal and dual variables, which incurs huge communication complexity; third, in T-ALADIN, a large-scale coupled QP has to be solved exactly, which results in heavy computation workload.

In this paper, we propose C-ALADIN for meeting the aforementioned challenges. C-ALADIN addresses the challenges as follows: First, instead of solving a coupled QP in T-ALADIN, a consensus QP is solved in C-ALADIN; second, we improve the upload and download communication efficiency by designing decoding strategies on both sides of the agents and the master. In detail, on the uploading side, we find that the local optimizer dominates such parameters. Such an observation, in conjunction with the approximation techniques of Broyden‚ÄìFletcher‚ÄìGoldfarb‚ÄìShanno (BFGS) [2], enable the master to recover the Hessian approximation matrices. It avoids uploading Hessian matrices directly from agents. We name the above techniques Consensus BFGS ALADIN. Later, in a reduced version named Reduced Consensus ALADIN, we simply use an identity matrix for large-scale computation problems. On the downloading side, inspired by the KKT (Karush‚ÄìKuhn‚ÄìTucker) optimality condition of the coupled QP, we allow the agents to recover the dual variables that are not urgently broadcast. It can be realized by decoding such variables with the help of the global variable; third, in C-ALADIN, the computational bottlenecks come from solving a large-scale sparse consensus QP that plays a key role in coordinating information. Inspired by the technique of KKT mentioned above, we find an equivalent form of the large-scale sparse consensus QP in C-ALADIN. Such a form can significantly release the burden on computing the corresponding KKT matrix. Based on our proposed C-ALADIN, we then propose a theory of convergence analysis, which works for both convex and non-convex cases.

In order to expand the application scope of our proposed C-ALADIN algorithm family, we next show how FL can benefit from our proposed C-ALADIN.

1.2 Federated Learning via Consensus ALADIN

FL, as a framework that aims to train a relatively universal model with data from different devices without transmitting the original data directly, involves many DC problems that are in general either convex or non-convex. In fact, there are several existing efforts [15, 8, 22, 23, 24, 25] on solving DC problems in FL. However, such algorithms typically suffer the bottleneck of lacking theoretical non-convex analysis and unsatisfactory convergence rate. To achieve both, we start adopting C-ALADIN in FL. Though C-ALADIN shows promising convergence performance, directly integrating C-ALADIN with FL is non-trivial. Specifically, all current members in C-ALADIN rely on uploading the local primal variables to the master, which is not secure. Then, because of the high-dimension property of FL, second order information can not be used, which limits the power of Consensus BFGS ALADIN. By observing such challenges, based on Reduced Consensus ALADIN, we design a novel variant member of C-ALADIN, named FedALADIN, that seamlessly meets the requirements of FL.

In summary, our key contributions of this paper are as follows:

a) We introduce the notion of consensus QP.

b) We propose a novel efficient algorithm family C-ALADIN that shows rigorous convergence guarantee, which consists of Consensus BFGS ALADIN and Reduced Consensus ALADIN.

c) We propose a novel proof framework to perform the convergence analysis of C-ALADIN.

d) We propose FedALADIN for FL.

e) We perform numerical experiments on both C-ALADIN and FedALADIN. The results say that both C-ALADIN and FedALADIN show significant improvements in convergence performance.

1.3 Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we provide mathematical preliminaries, including fundamentals of Consensus ADMM and T-ALADIN. In Section¬†3, we present a new algorithm named C-ALADIN. Moreover, we show that a reduced version of C-ALADIN can be applied to FL named FedALADIN in Section 4. Later, convergence theory of C-ALADIN is established in Section¬†5. In the end, we show the numerical result in Section¬†6 . In Section 7, we provide a literature review. Section 8 concludes this paper.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we provide formal fundamentals of Consensus ADMM and T-ALADIN.

Note that the uploaded information wisubscriptùë§ùëñw_{i}s from client side of Algorithm 1 is a linear combination of the local primal and the dual variables, which is a secure way of protecting clients‚Äô local information.

Remark 1.

The private variables xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} can be updated by applying any approximation technologies such as decentralized linearized alternating direction method of multipliers (DLM) [26] or decentralized quadratically approximated alternating direction method of multipliers (DQM) [27].

Remark 2.

As pointed out in [12, Section IV], a Consensus ADMM variation [11] was specifically designed for solving Problem (4) instead of Problem (1) and should be considered a relatively independent algorithm.

2.2 T-ALADIN in A Nutshell

T-ALADIN is the first distributed optimization algorithm that can generally solve non-convex DO (1).

In the first step, Algorithm¬†2 has a similar operation as ADMM and gets new local optimizers from each client. Later we evaluate the gradients gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i}s and positive definite Hessian matrices approximation HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}s with Œæi+superscriptsubscriptùúâùëñ\xi_{i}^{+}s. In the third step, we solve a large-scale QP for coordination by using gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i}s and HisubscriptùêªùëñH_{i}s from the second step. In the end, we send the updated primal and dual variables to each client in the forth step.

The main difference between ADMM and T-ALADIN is that the latter updates the global dual variable Œºùúá\mu by solving the constrained coupled QP (Equation (8)). Moreover, with the assumption of linearly independent constraint qualification (LICQ) and second order sufficient condition (SOSC), Algorithm¬†2 has local convergence guarantees for distributed non-convex problems [28].

Note that T-ALADIN tries to collect all the good properties of SQP and ADMM. There are two main extreme cases:

  • ‚Ä¢

    When œÅ‚Üí‚àû‚Üíùúå\rho\rightarrow\infty, the first step of Algorithm¬†2 is redundant and the whole structure is equivalent to SQP.

  • ‚Ä¢

    When œÅ‚Üí0‚Üíùúå0\rho\rightarrow 0, Algorithm¬†2 equals a combination of DD and Newton‚Äôs method.

Remark 3.

To the best of our knowledge, although a convex LASSO problem has been solved with T-ALADIN [18, Section 5.1], is a two objectives optimization problem. Besides, no such concept like consensus ALADIN has been formally proposed by others.

3 Consensus ALADIN

In Subsection 3.1, we propose the consensus QP.In Subsection¬†3.2, we detail our communication-efficient design. In Subsection¬†3.3, we provide our techniques that improve computational efficiency. In Subsection 3.4, with the techniques proposed in the above subsections, we formally describe C-ALADIN with two variants, namely Consensus BFGS ALADIN and Reduced Consensus ALADIN.

3.1 From Coupled QP to Consensus QP

Remember that in Subsection 1.1, T-ALADIN is struggling with solving Problem (4) because of the coupling equality constraints in Equation (8). Thus, the first step towards making T-ALADIN survive in (4) is to reconstruct Equation (8), which yields our consensus QP that is formally shown as follows:

minŒî‚Äãxi,z‚àëi=1N(12‚ÄãŒî‚Äãxi‚ä§‚ÄãBi‚ÄãŒî‚Äãxi+gi‚ä§‚ÄãŒî‚Äãxi)s.t.Œî‚Äãxi+xi+=z|Œªi.formulae-sequencesubscriptŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅ12Œîsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñtopsubscriptùêµùëñŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñtopŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñstŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñconditionalùëßsubscriptùúÜùëñ\begin{split}\mathop{\mathrm{\min}}_{\Delta x_{i},z}&\quad\mathop{\sum}_{i=1}^{N}\left(\frac{1}{2}\Delta x_{i}^{\top}B_{i}\Delta x_{i}+g_{i}^{\top}\Delta x_{i}\right)\\ \mathrm{s.t.}&\qquad\Delta x_{i}+x_{i}^{+}=z\;|\lambda_{i}.\end{split} (10)

It is trivial to see that, in (10), by introducing a global variable zùëßz and coupling all xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}s to zùëßz. The number of coupled equality constraints will be reduced to O‚Äã(N)ùëÇùëÅO(N) which is lower than O‚Äã(N2)ùëÇsuperscriptùëÅ2O(N^{2}) that comes from the direct adoption of T-ALADIN (shown as Figure 2 and 2). Note that, in Equation (10), we have one global primal variable zùëßz and NùëÅN dual variable, which is in contrast to the formulation of Equation (8).

After replacing Equation (8) with Equation (10), Algorithm 2 starts working in a consensus fashion. We name this C-ALADIN.

Remark 4.

Regarding the number of coupling constraints of T-ALADIN, we want to stress that O‚Äã(N2)ùëÇsuperscriptùëÅ2O(N^{2}), corresponding to the Figure 2, describes the worst case when directly adopting T-ALADIN in solving DC problems. As for the best case, though T-ALADIN can work under O‚Äã(N)ùëÇùëÅO(N) coupling constraints as those of C-ALADIN, it needs a fine-grained design on Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i}, which, from user‚Äôs perspective, hinders the ease of practical adoption of T-ALADIN.

3.2 Improve the Communication Efficiency of C-ALADIN

In this subsection, we jointly improve the upload 3.2.1 and download 3.2.2 communication efficiency of C-ALADIN.

3.2.1 Improving Upload Communication Efficiency

In the C-ALADIN framework, instead of solving Problem (6), we solve the following decoupled augmented loss function (11) with local dual ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i}.

xi+=arg‚Å°minxifi‚Äã(xi)+Œªi‚ä§‚Äãxi+œÅ2‚Äã‚Äñxi‚àíz‚Äñ2.superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñtopsubscriptùë•ùëñùúå2superscriptnormsubscriptùë•ùëñùëß2{x_{i}}^{+}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{x_{i}}f_{i}(x_{i})+\lambda_{i}^{\top}x_{i}+\frac{\rho}{2}\|x_{i}-z\|^{2}. (11)

In order to avoid uploading the gradient and Hessian approximation directly (7), we choose to decode the first and second order information on the master side, which is detailed in (12)

{gi‚Äã(xi+)=œÅ‚Äã(z‚àíxi+)‚àíŒªi((sub)gradient),si‚Äã(xi+,xi‚àí)=xi+‚àíxi‚àí,yi‚Äã(xi+,xi‚àí)=gi‚Äã(xi+)‚àígi‚àí,Bi+=Bi‚àíBi‚Äãsi‚Äãsi‚ä§‚ÄãBisi‚ä§‚ÄãBi‚Äãsi+yi‚Äãyi‚ä§si‚ä§‚Äãyi(BFGS update).\left\{\begin{split}&g_{i}(x_{i}^{+})=\;\rho(z-x_{i}^{+})-\lambda_{i}\quad\text{((sub)gradient)},\\ &s_{i}(x_{i}^{+},x_{i}^{-})=\;x_{i}^{+}-x_{i}^{-},\\ &y_{i}(x_{i}^{+},x_{i}^{-})=\;g_{i}(x_{i}^{+})-g_{i}^{-},\\ &B_{i}^{+}=\;B_{i}-\frac{B_{i}s_{i}s_{i}^{\top}B_{i}}{s_{i}^{\top}B_{i}s_{i}}+\frac{y_{i}y_{i}^{\top}}{s_{i}^{\top}y_{i}}\quad\text{(BFGS update)}.\end{split}\right. We want to stress several key designs behind Equation (12). First, we suppose that the augmented NLP (11) can be solved exactly. By applying Clarke sub-differential of fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i} at xi+superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}^{+}, we have gi=œÅ‚Äã(z‚àíxi+)‚àíŒªi‚àà‚àÇfisubscriptùëîùëñùúåùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñsubscriptùëìùëñg_{i}=\rho(z-x_{i}^{+})-\lambda_{i}\in\partial f_{i}. It means that the (sub)gradient can be decoded with xi+superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}^{+} without being transmitted.

Second, by applying the difference of local private variables and the local (sub)gradients, the BFGS Hessian approximation can also be decoded by the master. In order to ensure the positive definiteness of local BFGS matrices, we adopted the strategy of damped BFGS [2, Page 537], that is, we modify the local gradient difference yisubscriptùë¶ùëñy_{i}

Modified versions of BFGS may also work.For example, to solve the storage problem of the BFGS approximation Hessian, limited memory BFGS (L-BFGS) maybe a promising solution.

Remark 5.

If we are dealing with a single objective problem, instead of computing the inverse of Bi+superscriptsubscriptùêµùëñB_{i}^{+} directly, we have the following closed form:

(Bk+1)‚àí1=(Bk)‚àí1+(s‚ä§‚Äãy+y‚ä§‚Äã(Bk)‚àí1‚Äãy)‚Äã(s‚Äãs‚ä§)(s‚ä§‚Äãy)2‚àí(Bk)‚àí1‚Äãy‚Äãs‚ä§+s‚Äãy‚ä§‚Äã(Bk)‚àí1s‚ä§‚Äãy.superscriptsuperscriptùêµùëò11superscriptsuperscriptùêµùëò1superscriptùë†topùë¶superscriptùë¶topsuperscriptsuperscriptùêµùëò1ùë¶ùë†superscriptùë†topsuperscriptsuperscriptùë†topùë¶2superscriptsuperscriptùêµùëò1ùë¶superscriptùë†topùë†superscriptùë¶topsuperscriptsuperscriptùêµùëò1superscriptùë†topùë¶\begin{split}(B^{k+1})^{-1}=&(B^{k})^{-1}+\frac{(s^{\top}y+y^{\top}(B^{k})^{-1}y)(ss^{\top})}{(s^{\top}y)^{2}}\\ &-\frac{(B^{k})^{-1}ys^{\top}+sy^{\top}(B^{k})^{-1}}{s^{\top}y}.\end{split}

It can not be applied directly if we have a summation of BisubscriptùêµùëñB_{i}s.

3.2.2 Improving Download Communication Efficiency

If we express the Lagrange function of Equation¬†(10),

‚ÑíQP‚Äã(Œî‚Äãxi,z,Œªi)=(‚àëi=1N12‚ÄãŒî‚Äãxi‚ä§‚ÄãBi‚ÄãŒî‚Äãxi+gi‚ä§‚ÄãŒî‚Äãxi)+(‚àëi=1NŒªi‚ä§‚Äã(Œî‚Äãxi+xi+‚àíz)),superscript‚ÑíQPŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñùëßsubscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅ12Œîsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñtopsubscriptùêµùëñŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñtopŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñtopŒîsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëß\begin{split}\mathcal{L}^{\text{QP}}(\Delta x_{i},z,\lambda_{i})=&\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{2}\Delta x_{i}^{\top}B_{i}\Delta x_{i}+g_{i}^{\top}\Delta x_{i}\right)\\ &+\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{i}^{\top}(\Delta x_{i}+x_{i}^{+}-z)\right),\end{split} (13)

the KKT system can be then expressed in the following three equations,

{‚àÇ‚ÑíQP‚àÇŒî‚Äãxi=Bi‚ÄãŒî‚Äãxi+gi+Œªi=0,‚àÇ‚ÑíQP‚àÇŒªi=Œî‚Äãxi+xi+‚àíz=0,‚àÇ‚ÑíQP‚àÇz=‚àí‚àëi=1NŒªi=0,\left\{\begin{split}\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}^{\text{QP}}}{\partial\Delta x_{i}}&=B_{i}\Delta x_{i}+g_{i}+\lambda_{i}=0,\\ \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}^{\text{QP}}}{\partial\lambda_{i}}&=\Delta x_{i}+x_{i}^{+}-z=0,\\ \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}^{\text{QP}}}{\partial z}&=-\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{i}=0,\end{split}\right. (14)

which implies Œî‚Äãxi=z‚àíxi+Œîsubscriptùë•ùëñùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñ\Delta x_{i}=z-x_{i}^{+} and Œªi=Bi‚Äã(xi+‚àíz)‚àígisubscriptùúÜùëñsubscriptùêµùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëßsubscriptùëîùëñ\lambda_{i}=B_{i}(x_{i}^{+}-z)-g_{i}. It shows that agents can decode the dual variable ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i} with the global variable zùëßz without being transmitted.

In summary, in C-ALADIN, the agents only upload their private variables update xi+superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}^{+} to the master while the master broadcast the global variable (aggregate model) zùëßz. In this way, neither Hessian nor gradient needs to be uploaded and the dual variables need not to be downloaded.

Improving the communication efficiency mentioned above is not the end. To further enhance our algorithm, we next boost computational efficiency.

3.3 Improve the Computational Efficiency of C-ALADIN

To improve the computational efficiency, a trivial approach is to seek help from existing QP solvers which is described as follows: solvers based on active set qpOASES [29], MOSEK [30], GUROBI [31]; solvers based on interior point methods CVXGEN [32] and OOQP [33]; solvers basd on ADMM or operator splitting method OSQP [34].

However, such solvers ignore the special structure of our input (10). Therefore, a customized QP solver is needed for improving the computational efficiency. Next, we show our technical details.

The global primal variable can be updated in a cheap operation by introducing the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

With the decoding of Hessian approximation and the gradients of the agents by Equation (12), the global zùëßz can be updated as Equation (15) 222Assume that the matrix inverse operation can be applied on the master side, instead of an inverse operation, conjugate gradient descent can be also applied here. 333 Suppose that for iteration kùëòk with logK‚Äã(k)‚àà‚Ñïsubscriptlogùêæùëò‚Ñï\text{log}_{K}(k)\in\mathbb{N} [19], the Hessian matrices can be chosen optionally to upload from the agent to the master. The decomposition of a positive definite matrix can be prepared before the consensus QP step (10). .

Proof.

In this way, the operation burden of large-scale matrix inversion in Equation (16) is reduced.

By combining the technologies proposed in the above three subsections, we illustrate two variations of C-ALADIN in the next subsection.

3.4 Algorithm Structure

In this subsection, by combining our proposed techniques described in Subsection 3.1-3.3, we propose two algorithms. Specifically, one, named Consensus BFGS ALADIN, benefits from the techniques of BFGS Hessian approximation (with Equation (15)). The other, named Reduced Consensus ALADIN (with Equation (20)), under the scenario where the convergence rate is degraded, can work without the second-order information. We detail Consensus BFGS ALADIN in Algorithm 3. For Reduced Consensus ALADIN, it can be easily got from by replacing xi+superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}^{+}, ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i}, gisubscriptùëîùëñg_{i} and zùëßz in Algorithm 3 with the ones defined by the following equation:

{Œªi=œÅ‚Äã(xi‚àíz)‚àígi,xi+=arg‚Å°minxifi‚Äã(xi)+Œªi‚ä§‚Äãxi+œÅ2‚Äã‚Äñxi‚àíz‚Äñ2,gi=œÅ‚Äã(z‚àíxi+)‚àíŒªi,z=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1N(xi+‚àígiœÅ).\left\{\begin{split}&\lambda_{i}=\rho(x_{i}-z)-g_{i},\\ &{x_{i}}^{+}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{x_{i}}f_{i}(x_{i})+\lambda_{i}^{\top}x_{i}+\frac{\rho}{2}\|x_{i}-z\|^{2},\\ &g_{i}=\rho(z-x_{i}^{+})-\lambda_{i},\\ &z=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(x_{i}^{+}-\frac{g_{i}}{\rho}\right).\end{split}\right. (22)

Note that, both two algorithms belong to the class of C-ALADIN.

Remark 7.

As a supplement, we analyze the difference between the Reduced Consensus ALADIN and Consensus ADMM in Appendix A.

In order to expand the reach of our proposed C-ALADIN, by meeting the DC problems in FL, we next introduce a novel way of applying Reduced Consensus ALADIN in this area.

4 FedALADIN

To meet the DC problems in FL, directly adopting Consensus BFGS ALADIN or Reduced Consensus ALADIN is a straightforward approach to solving such problems. However, we will meet the following challenges: first, since the high dimension of private variables xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}s, we cannot benefit from the second order information; second, existing algorithms, when solving the DC problems in FL, does not carefully determine a training epoch, which makes the solutions inexact. This challenge renders the failure to directly adopting our techniques that provide exact solutions. By meeting the two challenges, in this section, we carefully design a variant of Reduced Consensus ALADIN, named FedALADIN, that works well for the problems in FL.

We sketch the key design of FedALADIN as follows: By following the conventions in Algorithm 1 and observing the structure of Equation (20), each client transmits Equation (25) instead of xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}.

wi=(xi‚àígiœÅ).subscriptùë§ùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëîùëñùúåw_{i}=\left(x_{i}-\frac{g_{i}}{\rho}\right). (25)

Next, we detail FedALADIN in Algorithm 4. Different from Algorithm¬†1, Algorithm¬†4 obtains the local optimizer by using the decoded ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i} from the previous global model zùëßz. Then we evaluate the (sub)gradients with Equation¬†(24). Later we encode the transmitted date wisubscriptùë§ùëñw_{i}s with Equation¬†(25). After receiving wisubscriptùë§ùëñw_{i}s from each client, the server aggregates them as FedADMM.

Note that the major difference between FedALADIN and FedADMM is the way of dual update. More importantly, the gradient evaluation (24) is a symmetric operation as the dual update of Equation¬†(45). However, FedALADIN can benefit from the reduced QP operation compare with the former. In terms of structure, all the existing algorithms in FL are special cases of FedALADIN.

In the next section, we aim to establish the global and local convergence theory of C-ALADIN.

5 Convergence Analysis

In this section, we are interested in the convergence behavior of C-ALADIN, which consists of the following three parts:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Global convergence of Reduced Consensus ALADIN for convex problems (Subsection 5.1).

  • ‚Ä¢

    Global linear convergence rate of Reduced Consensus ALADIN for Lipschitz continuous or strongly convex problems (Subsection 5.2).

  • ‚Ä¢

    Local convergence analysis of non-convex problems with C-ALADIN (Subsection 5.3).

Lemma 1.

With the procedure of Algorithm¬†1, the local primal update has a relationship with the local dual and global primal variables in the following way

Proof.

5.1 Global Convergence of Convex Case

The following global convergence proof relies on the Lyapunov stability theory in the control community. A relationship between the former and the latter has been clarified in Appendix B.

We assume that the sub-functions fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}s are closed, proper, and strictly convex. For establishing the global convergence theory of Reduced Consensus ALADIN, we introduce the following Lyapunov function [35] with the global minimizer z‚àósuperscriptùëßz^{*}.

‚Ñí‚Äã(z,Œª)=1œÅ‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªi‚àó‚Äñ2+œÅ‚ÄãN‚Äã‚Äñz‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ2.‚ÑíùëßùúÜ1ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptnormsubscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ2ùúåùëÅsuperscriptnormùëßsuperscriptùëß2\mathscr{L}(z,\lambda)=\frac{1}{\rho}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{*}\|^{2}+\rho N\|z-z^{*}\|^{2}. (33)

Note that the choice of Lyapunov function is not unique. Next, we will prove the global convergence of Reduced Consensus ALADIN by showing that the Lyapunov function is monotonically decreasing.

Theorem 2.

Suppose fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}s are strictly convex and problem¬†(4) has an existing solution z‚àósuperscriptùëßz^{*}, then

‚Ñí‚Äã(z,Œª)‚àí‚Ñí‚Äã(z+,Œª+)‚â•Œ±‚Äã(‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ)‚â•0‚ÑíùëßùúÜ‚ÑísuperscriptùëßsuperscriptùúÜùõºnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëß0\mathscr{L}(z,\lambda)-\mathscr{L}(z^{+},\lambda^{+})\geq\alpha\left(\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|\right)\geq 0 (34)

will hold by applying Reduced Consensus ALADIN. Here, Œ±ùõº\alpha is a class ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} function [35].

Proof.

See Appendix C. ‚àé

According to Theorem¬†2, the global convergence of Reduced Consensus ALADIN can be established. In order to prove the convergence of sequence (z,Œª)ùëßùúÜ(z,\lambda) to the global optimal solution pair (z‚àó,Œª‚àó)superscriptùëßsuperscriptùúÜ(z^{*},\lambda^{*}), we need to show the uniqueness of it.

Theorem 3.

We assume that Theorem¬†2 holds, which yields

{limk‚Üí‚àûzk=z‚àólimk‚Üí‚àûŒªk=Œª‚àó,\left\{\begin{split}\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}z^{k}&=z^{*}\\ \lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\lambda^{k}&=\lambda^{*},\\ \end{split}\right. (35)

where kùëòk denotes the index of iterations.

Proof.

See Appendix D. ‚àé

The above two theorems show the convergence of (z,Œª)ùëßùúÜ\left(z,\lambda\right). Later, we will show xisubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i} is also convergent in the following theorem.

If Theorem¬†2 holds, then we have xi‚Üíz‚àó‚Üísubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëßx_{i}\rightarrow z^{*}.

See Appendix E. ‚àé

From the above three theorems, a convergence of the sub-gradients of the agents can be also easily established.

Note that the global convergence proof only requires the strict convexity of objectives without smoothness and strongly convexity assumptions.

5.2 Global Linear Convergence Rate Analysis

Next we will prove the Q-linear convergence rate [2] by adding additional mfsubscriptùëöùëìm_{f} strongly convex or œâfsubscriptùúîùëì\omega_{f} smooth assumptions.

Theorem 7.

Suppose that ‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}) is mfsubscriptùëöùëìm_{f} strongly convex, and there exists a Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0 such that

Œ¥‚Äã‚Ñí‚Äã(z+,Œª+)‚â§4‚Äãmf‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ2,ùõø‚ÑísuperscriptùëßsuperscriptùúÜ4subscriptùëöùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëß2\delta\mathscr{L}(z^{+},\lambda^{+})\leq 4m_{f}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\right\|^{2}, (37)

then C-ALADIN is Q-linearly converging to a unique optimal solution with rate (11+Œ¥)11ùõø\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\delta}}\right).

Proof.

See Appendix G. ‚àé

In the Reduced Consensus ALADIN, we find the condition of mfsubscriptùëöùëìm_{f} strongly convex and œâfsubscriptùúîùëì\omega_{f} smooth are symmetric. Q-linearly convergent results can also be established later.

Corollary 1.

Suppose that ‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(xi)superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(x_{i}) is œâfsubscriptùúîùëì\omega_{f} smooth and convex, we have a similar result as Theorem 7, there exists a Œ¥>0ùõø0\delta>0 such that

Œ¥‚Äã‚Ñí‚Äã(z+,Œª+)‚â§4œâf‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Äñgi‚àígi‚àó‚Äñ2,ùõø‚ÑísuperscriptùëßsuperscriptùúÜ4subscriptùúîùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptnormsubscriptùëîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñ2\delta\mathscr{L}(z^{+},\lambda^{+})\leq\frac{4}{\omega_{f}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|g_{i}-g_{i}^{*}\right\|^{2}, (38)

then Reduced Consensus ALADIN can also Q-linearly converge to a unique optimal solution with a rate (11+Œ¥)11ùõø\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\delta}}\right).

Proof.

From the definition of œâfsubscriptùúîùëì\omega_{f} Lipschitz continuous [2]

‚Äñgi‚àígi‚àó‚Äñ‚â§œâf‚Äã‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ,normsubscriptùëîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñsubscriptùúîùëìnormsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëß\|g_{i}-g_{i}^{*}\|\leq\omega_{f}\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|, (39)

the following inequality can be obtained

1œâf‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Äñgi‚àígi‚àó‚Äñ2‚â§‚àëi=1N(xi+‚àíz‚àó)‚ä§‚Äã(gi‚àígi‚àó).1subscriptùúîùëìsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùëîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñ2superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëßtopsubscriptùëîùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëîùëñ\begin{split}\frac{1}{\omega_{f}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|g_{i}-g_{i}^{*}\|^{2}\leq\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\right)^{\top}\left(g_{i}-g_{i}^{*}\right).\end{split} (40)

Note that the right-hand side is the same equation as that of Equation (82). Such that, the later proof is similar to Theorem 7 and is not shown here. ‚àé

Therefore, Reduced Consensus ALADIN needs either mfsubscriptùëöùëìm_{f} strongly convex or œâfsubscriptùúîùëì\omega_{f} Lipschitz continuous to establish the global Q-linear convergence theory.

In the above two sections, we show the global convergence of Reduced Consensus ALADIN has a similar property as ADMM. But different from the latter, in the next section we will show local convergence analysis of non-convex cases of C-ALADIN.

If fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}s are non-convex, C-ALADIN can still converge with sufficient large œÅùúå\rho with different convergence rate in different situations of Œ≥ùõæ\gamma.

In this subsection, we illustrate the numerical performance of the proposed algorithm in FL. Here, FedADMM1 represents the method proposed by [25] that update the dual before global aggregation. FedADMM2, follows the order as [38]. The convergence performance of the two schemes is very different in logistic regression problem. It has to be pointed out that, in the optimization setting, there is only a little difference in performance between the two ADMM variations mentioned above, but in this experiment, we can see that they behave completely differently. This once again illustrates the fundamental difference between locally exact or inexactly search of the local primal variables. While this paper does not address this issue theoretically in C-ALADIN family, it still points out that it is an open question worthy of attention.

For further discussion, as shown in Figure (9) and (9), we find that when the hyperparameter œÅùúå\rho is set to the same value (œÅ=0.5ùúå0.5\rho=0.5 for linear regression and 0.050.050.05 for logistic regression). With a learning rate Œ∑=0.01ùúÇ0.01\eta=0.01 for all the algorithms, the convergence performance of FedALADIN is far better than the existing algorithms at least in these two examples. In addition, we found that FedADMM2 is not stably converged in the first several iterations.

7 Related Work

Existing distributed convex optimization algorithms can be roughly divided into two types: primal decomposition (PD) [39, 40, 41] and DD (also called Lagrangian decomposition). We refer [42, 43, 44, 45] as references for more details.

PD aims to partition the problem in a lower-upper level fashion, where the upper-level problem considers the lower-higher level problems by their optimal value functions which means control the private variables directly. Different from the former, the higher level problem influence the lower level ones by using dual variables (shadow price) in the DD structure. To the best of our knowledge, only few literature studied the theoretical comparison between PD and DD. However, numerically, [43, 44] showed that DD performances a better convergence rate compare with PD, however the degree of stability of convergence is the opposite in some applications. A discussion can be found in [46, Section I]. The efforts in PD and DD can be further categorized into the following two fashions, namely exact search and inexact search. Exact search comes from the optimization community while inexact search is drawn from the FL community.

In the PD family, representative algorithms of exact search are DGD [13] and EXTRA [14]. On the inexact search side, FedSGD [15], FedAvg [8], FedProx [22] and FedDANE [23] were proposed.

In the DD family, current techniques, consisting of consensus ADMM [38] and DD, only focus on distributed convex problems with exact search. In contrast, our proposed C-ALADIN has guarantee for non-convex problems. On the inexact search side, the state-of-the-art algorithm is FedADMM [24, 25, 47]. Our proposed FedALADIN extends this line of work by showing a more stable convergence performance than FedADMM.

8 Conclusion &\& Outlook

This paper proposed a novel distributed consensus algorithm family, named C-ALADIN, that is efficient in solving non-convex problems. In the framework of C-ALADIN, we proposed efficient structure for communication and computation efficiency. Based on the framework, depending on whether second order information is used, two variants of C-ALADIN are proposed, named Consensus BFGS ALADIN and Reduced Consensus ALADIN respectively. Finally, to serve the FL community, we compare a variant of Reduced Consensus ALADIN named FedALADIN with existing method in FL. It performs well with several case studies.

Other variants of C-ALADIN will be considered in the future to accommodate different types of optimization problems. More importantly, the convergence theory with local inexactly search in C-ALADIN is still lacking. Such theoretical supplement will assist the algorithm to be applied in more complex neural networks.

Appendix A Comparison between Reduced Consensus ALADIN and Consensus ADMM

In the standard Consensus ADMM framework, there are two different cases: a) first update the dual then aggregate (update the primal global variable), b) first aggregate then update the dual. In this subsection we will analyze the Reduced Consensus ALADIN from the above two perspectives. In order to distinguish the Reduced Consensus ALADIN from the Consensus ADMM, we use superscripts on key variables, such as ŒªisubscriptùúÜùëñ\lambda_{i} and zùëßz, to show difference.

A.1 First Update the Dual then Aggregate

Algorithm 1 shows the first fashion of Consensus ADMM: first update the dual then aggregate (45). In the optimization point of view, FedADMM is a modification of the current fashion.

{xi+=arg‚Å°minxifi‚Äã(xi)+(ŒªiADMM1)‚ä§‚Äãxi+œÅ2‚Äã‚Äñxi‚àíz‚Äñ2,(ŒªiADMM1)+=(ŒªiADMM1)+œÅ‚Äã(xi+‚àíz),(z+)ADMM1=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1N(xi++(ŒªiADMM1)+œÅ).\left\{\begin{split}&{x_{i}}^{+}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{x_{i}}f_{i}(x_{i})+(\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM1}})^{\top}x_{i}+\frac{\rho}{2}\|x_{i}-z\|^{2},\\ &(\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM1}})^{+}=(\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM1}})+\rho(x_{i}^{+}-z),\\ &(z^{+})^{\text{ADMM1}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(x_{i}^{+}+\frac{(\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM1}})^{+}}{\rho}\right).\\ \end{split}\right. (45)

Here ŒªiADMM1superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñADMM1\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM1}} denotes the dual variables of the current Consensus ADMM fashion. From the expression of the subgradients (24), one may find

ŒªiALADIN=œÅ‚Äã(xi‚àí‚àíz)‚àígi.superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñALADINùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëßsubscriptùëîùëñ\lambda_{i}^{\text{ALADIN}}=\rho(x_{i}^{-}-z)-g_{i}. (49)

is guaranteed only at the optimal point. On the opposite, with Reduced Consensus ALADIN (49),

‚àëi=1NŒªiALADIN=0superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñALADIN0\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{i}^{\text{ALADIN}}=0 (51)

is guaranteed in each iteration. Since the first version of Consensus ADMM can not bring the latest dual update back to each agent, the updating rule of the dual in Reduced Consensus ALADIN can be interpreted as a more efficient way for local primal variable update. The Reduced Consensus ALADIN framework makes better use of the consensus dual information.

A.2 First Aggregate then Update the Dual

As introduced in [3], Consensus ADMM can also be interpreted in another fashion:

{xi+=arg‚Å°minxifi‚Äã(xi)+(ŒªiADMM2)‚ä§‚Äãxi+œÅ2‚Äã‚Äñxi‚àíz‚Äñ2,(z+)ADMM2=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1N(xi++ŒªiADMM2œÅ),(ŒªiADMM2)+=(ŒªiADMM2)+œÅ‚Äã(xi+‚àíz+).\left\{\begin{split}&{x_{i}}^{+}=\mathop{\arg\min}_{x_{i}}f_{i}(x_{i})+(\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM2}})^{\top}x_{i}+\frac{\rho}{2}\|x_{i}-z\|^{2},\\ &(z^{+})^{\text{ADMM2}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(x_{i}^{+}+\frac{\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM2}}}{\rho}\right),\\ &(\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM2}})^{+}=(\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM2}})+\rho(x_{i}^{+}-z^{+}).\end{split}\right. (52)

With (52), Consensus ADMM can also converge for convex problems with guarantees. In this form, the update of ŒªiADMM2superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñADMM2\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM2}}s has the same property as Reduced Consensus ALADIN that guarantees

‚àëi=1NŒªiADMM2=0superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñADMM20\sum_{i=1}^{N}\lambda_{i}^{\text{ADMM2}}=0 (53)

in each iteration. In this way, the dual variables can also carry sensitivity information of the gap between the latest global variable zùëßz and the local variables xi+superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñx_{i}^{+}. However, the second version of Consensus ADMM can not upload the latest local dual (46) back to the master because of (53). Reduced Consensus ALADIN is more efficient for global variable aggregation compare with (52).

Even without Hessian information updated, the Reduced Consensus ALADIN can still inherit both of the benefits of two different Consensus ADMM variations. In fact, it can be treated as a combination of the them. The new designed structure provides both latest information of the dual to the agents and the master.

Appendix B Preliminaries of the Lyapunov Stability Theory

In this section, we demonstrate the intuition of proving the global convergence of C-ALADIN (Subsection 5.1 and 5.2). Roughly, we adopt the theory of Lyapunov stability in control community [35] for nonlinear systems. The rationale behind such is that the concept of global convergence in optimization has a similarity as stable around the origin in control.

We assume that a nonlinear system is described by œÇÀô=œï‚Äã(œÇ)Àôùúçitalic-œïùúç\dot{\varsigma}=\phi(\varsigma) where œÇùúç\varsigma is the state variable and œï‚Äã(‚ãÖ)italic-œï‚ãÖ\phi(\cdot) is a nonlinear mapping from ‚Ñù|œÇ|‚Üí‚Ñù|œÇ|‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùúçsuperscript‚Ñùùúç\mathbb{R}^{|\varsigma|}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{|\varsigma|} which denotes the dynamic of a system. Here we introduce an unbounded mapping, named Lyapunov function

Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ):‚Ñù|œÇ|‚Üí‚Ñù:Œ¶ùúç‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùúç‚Ñù\Phi(\varsigma):\mathbb{R}^{|\varsigma|}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} (54)

Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ)Œ¶ùúç\Phi(\varsigma) has the following key properties:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ)Œ¶ùúç\Phi(\varsigma) is strictly monotonically decreasing along the trajectories of the system, in other words Œ¶Àô=‚àáxŒ¶‚ä§‚Äãœï<0ÀôŒ¶subscript‚àáùë•superscriptŒ¶topitalic-œï0\dot{\Phi}=\nabla_{x}\Phi^{\top}\phi<0.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ)>0Œ¶ùúç0\Phi(\varsigma)>0 if œÇ‚â†0ùúç0\varsigma\neq 0; otherwise, Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ)=0Œ¶ùúç0\Phi(\varsigma)=0.

With the above properties, we have the following theorem.

Theorem 9.

If Œ¶Œ¶\Phi is positive definite, bounded from below, and strictly monotonically decreasing, then œÇùúç\varsigma is bounded and converges to 00 (stable around the origin) [35].

Proof.

We next prove that œÇ‚Üí0‚Üíùúç0\varsigma\rightarrow 0 by showing the following contradiction:

We assume that œÇùúç\varsigma is not convergent to 00, then we have Œ¶Àô<0ÀôŒ¶0\dot{\Phi}<0. From the fundamental theorem of calculus, we then have

Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ0)‚â•Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ‚àû)=Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ0)+‚à´0‚àûŒ¶Àô‚Äã(œÇ)‚èü<0=‚àí‚àû.Œ¶superscriptùúç0Œ¶superscriptùúçŒ¶superscriptùúç0subscript‚èüsuperscriptsubscript0ÀôŒ¶ùúçabsent0\Phi(\varsigma^{0})\geq\Phi(\varsigma^{\infty})=\Phi(\varsigma^{0})+\underbrace{\int_{0}^{\infty}\dot{\Phi}(\varsigma)}_{<0}=-\infty. (55)

However, this shows a contradiction to the positive definiteness of and bounded below of Œ¶Œ¶\Phi. Hence we have

Œ¶‚Äã(œÇ)‚Üí0which impliesœÇ‚Üí0.formulae-sequence‚ÜíŒ¶ùúç0which implies‚Üíùúç0\Phi(\varsigma)\rightarrow 0\quad\text{which implies}\quad\varsigma\rightarrow 0.

‚àé

Theorem 9 states that the system under analysis is stable when the correlation property of the related Lyapunov function holds. Note that the existence of a Lyapunov function is only a sufficient condition to prove the stability around the origin. However we can not confirm that the system is unstable if we can not find a proper Lyapunov function. In our proof, if we treat the optimization algorithms as the nonlinear dynamic œï‚Äã(œÇ)italic-œïùúç\phi(\varsigma) of the control systems, and the gap between the decision variable and the optimizer as the state œÇùúç\varsigma, then the stable around the origin analysis is equivalent to prove the global convergence of optimization algorithms.

Appendix C Proof of Theorem 2

Proof.

First we introduce two auxiliary functions f~isubscript~ùëìùëñ\tilde{f}_{i} and G‚Äã(Œæ)ùê∫ùúâG(\xi):

{f~i‚Äã(Œæi)=fi‚Äã(Œæi)+(Œªi+œÅ‚Äã(xi+‚àíz))‚ä§‚ÄãŒæiG‚Äã(Œæ)=‚àëi=1Nfi‚Äã(Œæi)+‚àëi=1N(Œæi‚àíz‚àó)‚ä§‚ÄãŒªi‚àó.\left\{\begin{split}\tilde{f}_{i}(\xi_{i})&=f_{i}(\xi_{i})+(\lambda_{i}+\rho(x_{i}^{+}-z))^{\top}\xi_{i}\\ G(\xi)&=\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\xi_{i})+\sum_{i=1}^{N}(\xi_{i}-z^{*})^{\top}\lambda_{i}^{*}.\end{split}\right. (56)

Assume fisubscriptùëìùëñf_{i}s are strictly convex, then we have

{f~i‚Äã(xi+)‚â§f~i‚Äã(z‚àó)‚àíŒ±~i‚Äã(‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ)G‚Äã(z‚àó)‚â§G‚Äã(x+)‚àíŒ±^‚Äã(‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ)\left\{\begin{split}\tilde{f}_{i}(x_{i}^{+})&\leq\tilde{f}_{i}(z^{*})-\tilde{\alpha}_{i}(\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|)\\ G(z^{*})&\leq G(x^{+})-\hat{\alpha}(\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|)\end{split}\right. (57)

where Œ±~i‚Äã(‚ãÖ)subscript~ùõºùëñ‚ãÖ\tilde{\alpha}_{i}(\cdot) and Œ±^‚Äã(‚ãÖ)^ùõº‚ãÖ\hat{\alpha}(\cdot) are class ùí¶ùí¶\mathcal{K} functions. If we sum up the first equation of (57),

‚àëi=1N{fi‚Äã(xi+)‚àífi‚Äã(z‚àó)}‚â§‚àëi=1N{(Œªi++œÅ‚Äã(xi+‚àíz))‚ä§‚Äã(z‚àó‚àíxi+)}‚àí‚àëi=1NŒ±~i‚Äã(‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ).superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùëìùëñsuperscriptùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñùëßtopsuperscriptùëßsuperscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsubscript~ùõºùëñdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëß\begin{split}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\{f_{i}(x_{i}^{+})-f_{i}(z^{*})\right\}\leq&\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\{(\lambda_{i}^{+}+\rho(x_{i}^{+}-z))^{\top}(z^{*}-x_{i}^{+})\right\}\\ &-\sum_{i=1}^{N}\tilde{\alpha}_{i}(\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|).\end{split} (58)

Similarly, from the fact that

Combine Equations (58) and (59), we have

where

By trivially decomposing Equation (61), we get the following six parts

  • Part¬†1
    ‚àëi=1N(Œªi‚àíŒªi‚àó)‚ä§‚Äã(Œªi+‚àíŒªi2‚ÄãœÅ)=(‚Äã31‚Äã)‚àí14‚ÄãœÅ‚Äã‚àëi=1N(‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªi‚àó‚Äñ2‚àí‚ÄñŒªi+‚àíŒªi‚àó‚Äñ2+‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªi+‚Äñ2).superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñtopsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñ2ùúåitalic-(31italic-)14ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ2\begin{split}&\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{*}\right)^{\top}\left(\frac{\lambda_{i}^{+}-\lambda_{i}}{2\rho}\right)\\ \overset{\eqref{eq: quadratic equality}}{=}&\frac{-1}{4\rho}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{*}\|^{2}-\|\lambda_{i}^{+}-\lambda_{i}^{*}\|^{2}+\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{+}\|^{2}\right).\end{split} (62)

This says that the introduced Lyapunov function is monotonically decreasing. ‚àé

Appendix D Proof of Theorem 3

Proof.

As we have proved, ‚Ñí‚Äã(z,Œª)‚â•‚Ñí‚Äã(z+,Œª+)‚ÑíùëßùúÜ‚ÑísuperscriptùëßsuperscriptùúÜ\mathscr{L}(z,\lambda)\geq\mathscr{L}(z^{+},\lambda^{+}) and ‚Ñí‚Äã(z,Œª)‚ÑíùëßùúÜ\mathscr{L}(z,\lambda) is bounded below.

We assume that the sequence pair (xi,Œªi)subscriptùë•ùëñsubscriptùúÜùëñ(x_{i},\lambda_{i}) has at least two limit points (zŒ±,ŒªiŒ±)superscriptùëßùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõº(z^{\alpha},\lambda_{i}^{\alpha}) and (zŒ≤,ŒªiŒ≤)superscriptùëßùõΩsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõΩ(z^{\beta},\lambda_{i}^{\beta}), such that

{‚ÑíŒ±‚Äã(z,Œª)=1œÅ‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªiŒ±‚Äñ2+œÅ‚ÄãN‚Äã‚Äñz‚àízŒ±‚Äñ2‚ÑíŒ≤‚Äã(z,Œª)=1œÅ‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªiŒ≤‚Äñ2+œÅ‚ÄãN‚Äã‚Äñz‚àízŒ≤‚Äñ2.\left\{\begin{split}\mathscr{L}^{\alpha}(z,\lambda)=\frac{1}{\rho}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{\alpha}\|^{2}+\rho N\|z-z^{\alpha}\|^{2}\\ \mathscr{L}^{\beta}(z,\lambda)=\frac{1}{\rho}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{\beta}\|^{2}+\rho N\|z-z^{\beta}\|^{2}.\end{split}\right. (69)

We hypothesize that they may converge to different value

{limk‚Üí‚àû‚ÑíŒ±‚Äã(z,Œª)=LŒ±limk‚Üí‚àû‚ÑíŒ≤‚Äã(z,Œª)=LŒ≤.\left\{\begin{split}\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\mathscr{L}^{\alpha}(z,\lambda)=L^{\alpha}\\ \lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}\mathscr{L}^{\beta}(z,\lambda)=L^{\beta}.\end{split}\right. (70)

Note that

‚ÑíŒ±‚Äã(z,Œª)‚àí‚ÑíŒ≤‚Äã(z,Œª)=œÅ‚ÄãN‚Äã(‚Äñz‚àízŒ±‚Äñ2‚àí‚Äñz‚àízŒ≤‚Äñ2)+1œÅ‚Äã‚àëi=1N(‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªiŒ±‚Äñ2‚àí‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªiŒ≤‚Äñ2).superscript‚ÑíùõºùëßùúÜsuperscript‚ÑíùõΩùëßùúÜùúåùëÅsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëßsuperscriptùëßùõº2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëßsuperscriptùëßùõΩ21ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõº2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõΩ2\begin{split}&\mathscr{L}^{\alpha}(z,\lambda)-\mathscr{L}^{\beta}(z,\lambda)\\ =&\rho N\left(\|z-z^{\alpha}\|^{2}-\|z-z^{\beta}\|^{2}\right)\\ &+\frac{1}{\rho}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{\alpha}\|^{2}-\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{\beta}\|^{2}\right).\end{split} (71)

For the first part,

œÅ‚ÄãN‚Äã(‚Äñz‚àízŒ±‚Äñ2‚àí‚Äñz‚àízŒ≤‚Äñ2)=œÅ‚ÄãN‚Äã((zŒ±‚àízŒ≤)‚ä§‚Äã(zŒ±+zŒ≤‚àí2‚Äãz)).ùúåùëÅsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëßsuperscriptùëßùõº2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëßsuperscriptùëßùõΩ2ùúåùëÅsuperscriptsuperscriptùëßùõºsuperscriptùëßùõΩtopsuperscriptùëßùõºsuperscriptùëßùõΩ2ùëß\begin{split}&\rho N\left(\|z-z^{\alpha}\|^{2}-\|z-z^{\beta}\|^{2}\right)\\ =&\rho N\left(\left(z^{\alpha}-z^{\beta}\right)^{\top}\left(z^{\alpha}+z^{\beta}-2z\right)\right).\\ \end{split} (72)

Similarly, the second part can be expressed as

1œÅ‚Äã‚àëi=1N(‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªiŒ±‚Äñ2‚àí‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªiŒ≤‚Äñ2)=1œÅ‚Äã‚àëi=1N((ŒªiŒ±‚àíŒªiŒ≤)‚ä§‚Äã(ŒªiŒ±+ŒªiŒ≤‚àí2‚ÄãŒªi)).1ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõº2superscriptdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõΩ21ùúåsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõΩtopsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõºsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùõΩ2subscriptùúÜùëñ\begin{split}&\frac{1}{\rho}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{\alpha}\|^{2}-\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{\beta}\|^{2}\right)\\ =&\frac{1}{\rho}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\left(\left(\lambda_{i}^{\alpha}-\lambda_{i}^{\beta}\right)^{\top}\left(\lambda_{i}^{\alpha}+\lambda_{i}^{\beta}-2\lambda_{i}\right)\right).\end{split} (73)

Therefore,

Appendix H Proof of Theorem 8

Proof.

First, let the result of Equation¬†(77)-(80) holds, four different situations of local convergence analysis of C-ALADIN can be established by combing with SQP theory [2, Chapter 18]. First, we show the local convergence analysis of Reduced Consensus ALADIN. As an extension, the corresponding analysis of Consensus BFGS ALADIN is also discussed.

As mentioned in Section 3.4, Reduced Consensus ALADIN is proposed by setting Bi=œÅ‚ÄãIsubscriptùêµùëñùúåùêºB_{i}=\rho I. Assume Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is the upper bound of the Hessian approximation distance, ‚ÄñœÅ‚ÄãI‚àí‚àá2fi‚Äã(xi)‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥normùúåùêºsuperscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùõæ\left\|\rho I-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(x_{i})\right\|\leq\gamma, the convergence rate analysis can be divided into four situations. From the SQP theory of Newton Lagrange method [49], we have different convergence rate guarantees for the first three situations of the following four.

a) If ‚ÄñœÅ‚ÄãI‚àí‚àá2fi‚Äã(xi)‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥‚â§1normùúåùêºsuperscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñùõæ1\left\|\rho I-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(x_{i})\right\|\leq\gamma\leq 1, we have

{N‚Äã‚Äñz+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ‚àëi=1N‚ÄñŒªi+‚àíŒªi‚àó‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ.\left\{\begin{split}N\|z^{+}-z^{*}\|&\leq\gamma\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|\\ \sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\lambda_{i}^{+}-\lambda_{i}^{*}\|&\leq\gamma\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|.\end{split}\right. (97)

Conbine Equation (80) and (97), the following inequality can be obtained.

(œÅ‚ÄãNœÉ‚Äã‚Äñ(z+‚àíz‚àó)‚Äñ+1œÉ‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Äñ(Œªi+‚àíŒªi‚àó)‚Äñ)‚â§(œÅ+1)‚ÄãŒ≥œÉ‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚Äñxi+‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ‚â§(‚Äã80‚Äã)(œÅ+1)‚ÄãŒ≥œÉ‚Äã(œÅ‚ÄãNœÉ‚Äã‚Äñz‚àíz‚àó‚Äñ+1œÉ‚Äã‚àëi=1N‚ÄñŒªi‚àíŒªi‚àó‚Äñ).ùúåùëÅùúédelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptùëßsuperscriptùëß1ùúésuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñùúå1ùõæùúésuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅdelimited-‚à•‚à•superscriptsubscriptùë•ùëñsuperscriptùëßitalic-(80italic-)ùúå1ùõæùúéùúåùëÅùúédelimited-‚à•‚à•ùëßsuperscriptùëß1ùúésuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅdelimited-‚à•‚à•subscriptùúÜùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùúÜùëñ\begin{split}&\left(\frac{\rho N}{\sigma}\|(z^{+}-z^{*})\|+\frac{1}{\sigma}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|(\lambda_{i}^{+}-\lambda_{i}^{*})\|\right)\\ \leq&\frac{\left(\rho+1\right)\gamma}{\sigma}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|x_{i}^{+}-z^{*}\|\\ \overset{\eqref{eq: con_ALADIN_step1}}{\leq}&\frac{\left(\rho+1\right)\gamma}{\sigma}\left(\frac{\rho N}{\sigma}\|z-z^{*}\|+\frac{1}{\sigma}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\lambda_{i}-\lambda_{i}^{*}\|\right).\end{split} (98)

where œâfsubscriptùúîùëì\omega_{f} denotes the corresponding Lipschitz constant [2]. This shows a quadratic convergence of C-ALADIN.

Reduced Consensus ALADIN will show a local superlinear convergence.

d) If Œ≥ùõæ\gamma is large, the above analysis can not be applied. Luckily, if œÅùúå\rho is sufficient large, Equation (11) is locally strongly convex. Corollary (1) can be prepared here with different Œ¥ksuperscriptùõøùëò\delta^{k} in each iteration kùëòk. Therefore, assume there exist a Œ¥¬Ø‚â•Œ¥k¬Øùõøsuperscriptùõøùëò\bar{\delta}\geq\delta^{k} and satisfies Equation (38), then Reduced Consensus ALADIN can still get Q-linearly converge with rate (11+Œ¥¬Ø)11¬Øùõø\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{1+\bar{\delta}}}\right).

By recovering the Hessian approximation BisubscriptùêµùëñB_{i} with Equation (12), Consensus BFGS ALADIN can touch linear or super-linear convergence rate, since ‚ÄñBi‚àí‚àá2fi‚Äã(xi)‚Äñ‚Üí0‚Üínormsubscriptùêµùëñsuperscript‚àá2subscriptùëìùëñsubscriptùë•ùëñ0\|B_{i}-\nabla^{2}f_{i}(x_{i})\|\rightarrow 0 can easily hold. With the technologies of Sharpen BFGS [50], super-linear or even quadratic rate can be obtained. ‚àé

Remark 8.

Although the SQP type algorithms has local convergence guarantees for non-convex optimization problems, the performance depends on the initial point and the way of combined globalization technologies. Although ALADIN inherits the local convergence properties of SQP, the consensus globalization technologies (i.e. Armijo line search or trust region method [2]) are not needed.
